In addition to that, we are committed to level pricing for banks of all sizes, we've made that commitment publicly, we understand the history of the ACH where we had a level pricing structure. But the Fed came in and offered steep volume discounts in order to try to lure banks away from The--The Clearing House's ACH service. That's the source of the caveat that we've made.

In real-time payment system clearing which is the transmission of the payment message happens alongside settlement. They--they are not bifurcated at all. They happen at the same time and they happen instantaneously. So from the time I hit send to send you money, Senator Moran, to the time that money is in your account and you've got access to it is literally milliseconds. Because of that architecture, which is architected in the way that the Federal Reserve's Faster Payments Task Force sort of set out the criteria, it wanted a real-time payment system, you can't bifurcate those processes.

So it's not like the ACH, which is interoperable for transmission of the message only. But settlement happens at a later time because clearing and settlement transmission of the message and final payment happened immediately. Those two things aren't separated. And you can't interoperate in that regard. Both--both the sending bank and the receiving bank have to be on the same system. They have to be able to talk to each other instantaneously. And they have to work in such a way that those funds are transferred and available immediately. So we are not optimistic that these two systems will be interoperable.

So and I would also say that the problem of trust is one of the reasons why I don't think RTP has gotten traction, if there was trust, it was a great service, who--who would care whether the Fed's going to come in any way? People will be jumping for it. But that's not happening. The public comment processes has overwhelmingly said that pretty much everybody outside the big banks who own TCH want an alternative system.

VAN HOLLEN: Thank you. I look, I think the history shows that competition actually spurs innovation not stifles innovation.

Thank you, Mr. Chairman.

CRAPO: Thank you. Senator Kennedy.

KENNEDY: Thank you, Mr. Chairman.

This debate and I haven't made up my mind on this, that this debate reminds me a lot of the debate we're having in health care about whether--whether the United States government should set up its--its own health insurance program to compete with the private sector. That's just an observation.

Second observation, Mr. Steen, I have great respect for the Fed. And I would remind you, though, that it was the Fed, or at least people influencing the Fed, who decided in 2008, that the community banks were just as responsible as the too big to fail banks for the meltdown, which was patently untrue. And some people around here decided to try to regulate you and your colleagues half to death. And which, I think--I think hurt the banking system. So I'd be-- I'd just caution you up here in Washington, don't trust anybody too much.

(LAUGHTER)

President George, let me ask you this. And this is honestly a question. I don't mean the question to suggest an answer. Tell me what's wrong with RTP? Right? Is it not working? Can it not work? What's your concern?

GEORGE: So I have no insight to the functioning of RTP. But we have encouraged private sector innovation in this space. And for many years--

KENNEDY: --Well can I stop you a second? If you have no insight into RTP, then why do you want to set up something to compete with it?

GEORGE: Because our interest in making sure under our public policy goals, that access is broadly achieved for this service extends to some 10,000 institutions in this country and we have an existing network reach and relationship with those institutions.

KENNEDY: I get that and I'm sorry to interrupt you. But I don't know--what--what I want to understand. I mean, doesn't Fed have enough to do? It would just seem to me that--that if RTP can work, if you want to compete with it, that may be the right approach. But what I'm trying to understand is why?

GEORGE: Our interest--

KENNEDY: --I understand you have the power to do it. But why does it make sense to spend taxpayer money for the RTP--for the Fed to go set up a competitor for something that may be working? Unless it isn't, if it didn't work then tell me.

GEORGE: The information we took from the Private Sector Task Force came to the Fed and said, "We need the Fed to get into providing real-time payments with the private sector."

KENNEDY: Why?

GEORGE: The reason was to achieve broad reach. We have many community banks in this country that are in rural and remote areas that would not otherwise be profitable places to provide services. They need these services for their communities. They need to be able to attach to systems that might otherwise be out of their reach.

KENNEDY: May I stop you a minute because my--I'm not trying to be rude. Our time goes so fast.

GEORGE: Yes, sir.

KENNEDY: So why don't I mean, the Fed has the power to punish banks the rest of their natural lives. You and I both know that. I know you don't put it in those terms. And I'm not suggesting anything untoward. But so why don't you turn to our RTP and saying, "Look, here's some changes we would like to respectfully ask you to make. You don't have to make them but our advice is you should." They're not going to ignore you. Are they?

GEORGE: I think our experiences as operating alongside the private sector has produced the best outcomes for the payment system.

KENNEDY: Yeah, but--but--but--but--but my question is, if you see a way to improve the--I'm trying to understand, if you see a way to improve RTP, why don't you just sit down with them and say, "Folks, here we want you to--we want you to extend your reach, we want you to--to give us jurisdiction over the prices are going to charge and we want to make sure that you make your service available to everybody"? Boom, problem solved.

GEORGE: The Board of Governors don't--

KENNEDY: --And you save a bunch of time and money and you don't have to set up a competing system because taxpayers are going to pay for what you gonna set up. And I know you have enough to do.

GEORGE: We certainly have enough to do and we are intent on fulfilling our public policy authorities as Congress has granted us in this arena, which is to make sure that that system is accessible, that it's provided equitably, and that it is safe. And we will continue to operate alongside the private sector in achieving those outcomes for the public.

KENNEDY: Okay. Can I ask one more, Mr. Chairman, since it's just you? Oh, I'm sorry. I don't want to cut into Senator Smith's time.

But I thank--

SMITH: --Go ahead, Senator. One more, just one more.

(LAUGHTER)

KENNEDY: Well, Ms. Bair, is raising her hand.

BAIR: Well, I did. I just wanted to--to strongly support what President George said and indicate that I hear get what you're saying about--so first of all, they don't have regulatory authority, I think. So there is no direct authority to do rate regulation and access controls and all the kinds--

KENNEDY: --Yeah, but they're not--

BAIR: --you would find with the public utility.--

KENNEDY: --We live in the real world. The--the banks aren't going to ignore--

BAIR: --Mr.--if I could just--

KENNEDY: The banks aren't going to ignore the Fed--

BAIR: --Well--

KENNEDY: --if the Fed tells them to do something.

BAIR: --I wish that was true. But as--as a Republican and as somebody who I consider myself market-oriented, I think competition is a much better discipline on pricing, equity, and efficiency, and broadening customer bases, than trying to prescriptively, regulate this.

KENNEDY: So that's one--

BAIR: --The problem--

KENNEDY: --view. Another point of view is you just want to expand government.

BAIR: No, I--I don't think that's what the Fed's--look I've worked with the Fed for a long time. And I've criticized--you know, other parts of the Fed, I advocated for limits on the Fed's bailout authority. They probably weren't happy with me. Chairman Crapo remembers that in Dodd-Frank. So in other context--you know, sure, the Fed's got a lot of power. But this is like bread and butter of what they do. And they are the only ones who can come in with it with an alternative parallel system because of the--the costs and--and the--and the resources that are required to do this. If you just rely on private enterprise, there will be a single monopoly provider without the regulatory authority to impose pricing and access controls.

So I do think that the Fed is absolutely--this is in the public interest to do and it will be more efficient than just trying to regulate it with authority they don't have and--and I think big banks push back quite a bit against the Fed and the FDIC, so I would not say that they always do what the regulator asked them to.

KENNEDY: Thank you, Mr. Chairman. I'm sorry, Senator.

CRAPO: Senator Smith.

SMITH: Thank you, Mr. Chair, and I just realized I might have accidentally taken some of your authority by ceding time to Senator Kennedy without your permission. I'm--

CRAPO: --No problem. You're welcome.

(LAUGHTER)

KENNEDY: You're--you're on double-secret probation.

(LAUGHTER)

SMITH: I want to thank all the panelists for being here today. And I'm sorry, I missed the back and forth with my colleagues because as you no doubt heard we have lots of committee hearings today. But--so I just have--I'm sure the ground has been well plowed here.

Let me just ask a question of President George. President George, the Fed operates several payment systems already. And I'm wondering what you've learned about fraud prevention, from that experience. You know, one of the--there are many upsides to real-time payments. But of course, one of the possible downsides is real-time fraud. So could you just share a little bit about what you've learned about that?

GEORGE: So the security of the payment system is essential. And I think, as you've noted, in particular, when payments are moving this quickly, so we would see as part of our initiative, and as we did with the Private Sector Task Force is thinking about security, and what fraud mitigation standards will be important. And I think that will include education efforts--

SMITH: --Okay.--

GEORGE: --the banking system, making sure that their customers understand what role they play in that.

SMITH: Thank you. Would anybody else like to comment on that fraud question?

HUNTER: Absolutely, Senator. So we--we take consumer protection very seriously. We worked closely with the CFPB in our design and--and establishment of the system. And we've learned a lot about fraud from our interactions with--with other real-time payment systems around the world.

Fundamentally, the way we've architected this system is a much better, much more safe, much more secure experience for consumers and businesses because these are credit push payments only. So the consumer or the business actually have to actually authenticate into their banking system. And the only way that they can make a payment is to push those funds out.

There are no debit polls where if somebody gets a hold of your account information and they can defeat the fraud control systems at the bank, they can get money out of your account. So fundamentally, this is a much more safe, much more efficient, much more sound way for consumers to make payments.

And if I can, Senator, I just want to say that--that--you know, we will certainly work and to have discussions with the Fed about interoperability, I don't mean to imply to anyone that we are not concerned and wouldn't want to get there. When we talked about designing the system, we had hoped that interoperability could be achieved. We're not optimistic but we are certainly willing to do everything possible to discuss with the Fed and try to reach that result.

SMITH: Thank you.

Just another question that is very specific. It was raised to me specifically from Minnesota credit unions, of which we have many, and they're very important to communities in Minnesota, is small credit unions are trying to figure out--you know, they don't have staff available 24 hours a day, to monitor transactions and troubleshoot problems. And so my question to the panel is how can small institutions prepare to handle a payment system that would be on 24 hours a day? Like what would be the solutions, just the operability solutions for small institutions?

HUNTER: Senator, if I--if I may, we have worked very, very closely with third-party service providers. And one of the things that we've recognized is that they are going to need banks like Mr. Steen's bank, other community banks, we want all of those banks to be on the--on the RTP network because the network is only as valuable as the banks that it can reach. So third-party service providers, bankers, banks, corporate credit unions, other institutions that provide critical services, back-office services to small community banks and credit unions have been on our radar ever since we designed the system, what you have seen are large banks who--who handle their own technology coming onto the system to date. What you haven't seen but is equally important and what is maturing, is the work that we've done with those third-party service providers to bring small financial institutions onto the system. They have begun to be in a position to--to activate those core back-office systems. And they're going to start bringing on small community banks and credit unions in the next several months.

SMITH: Thank you. President George, would you like to respond?

GEORGE: So this is a real issue for smaller institutions, credit unions, small banks, and we will be working carefully around standards, which I think helped them in adhering to things that protect them and protect their customers.

SMITH: Thank you. And just one last question. So I'm just--let's say--let's say I'm just a person, which I am. And I'm trying to--and I can see that real-time payments--you know, whether I'm a small business and it's going to be helpful to me. So can anybody explain to me what is the harm of more competition? If I'm--to me, how am I harmed as an individual if there is more competition, rather than less competition in this--in this market?

HUNTER: Senator--

SMITH: I'm just--asked Ms.--Ms. Bair about this.

BAIR: Well, I think consumers are helped. It will result in more innovation, more competition, better pricing, wider access. I think absolutely two systems will support consumers and their ability to--to have a choice of real-time payment services and for all banks of all sizes of depository institutions, including credit unions of all sizes, to be able to participate in and--and this is the future. We will have real-time payments. And so that the challenge is to make sure-- make sure everybody's included. Having these two systems is the best way to do that.

HUNTER: Senator, if I'm may--

SMITH: --I'm sorry but I think Mr. Selgin was going to speak.

SELGIN: Oh, yes, I was going to say--

SMITH: --I'll let you.

SELGIN: Yes, I'm not one of those who opposes competition between the Fed and the private sector, including The Clearing House. What I--what I'm concerned with is that the competition has to be fair, if any of the players can cheat, or can compete unfairly, to put it a little bit more mildly, that can upset the competitive process that normally leads to good results. That's why we have the antitrust division, for example, to make sure private firms don't compete. In the Fed's case, we have to take--there are other precautions that are needed, some are taken already. But there are many ways in which presently the Fed can compete unfairly. And a few have been mentioned.

One of them is not paying interest on reserves held in joint accounts that serve the same purpose as other reserves, not--not classifying--sorry, funds in those accounts as reserves. They should be classified that way. Another is by not making its essential clearing services, settlement services on Fedwire and on NSS available 24/7. That allows other non-real-time payment systems to compete more effectively by having faster payments but not necessarily not real-time payments. And there's competition on that margin too.

So there are a lot of steps Congress can take to assure that competition is even--is played on--on an even playing field, a level playing field between the Fed and the private sector. That's the key, not preventing competition.

HUNTER:

--And Senator, if--if I may, we are not against competition, let me make that perfectly clear. What we are concerned about is an unlevel playing field between the private sector and--and the government. We are also concerned that if we can't figure out interoperability and no, no systems worldwide interoperate in real-time gross settlement payments like we've set up here. They haven't--nobody's figured out how to do that yet. That will lead to a very suboptimal result in this country for consumers and businesses where the participants and their customers on one system aren't going to be able to complete payments to the participants and their customers on another system.

SMITH: Thank you, Mr. Chair.

CRAPO: Thank you. And that completes the questioning, although I'm going to ask for a brief response from all of you on an issue that Senator Cortez Masto raised. But first, let me thank you all for bringing this perspective here. We have the obvious divergence of opinions on the committee here about this issue. I find it interesting, I think Senator Kennedy, probably focused on the dichotomy.

We--we all believe in competition, we also all talk about how we believe in not having the government be too large. And--and having the government step in here. What we're talking about is the government competing with the private sector. And--and that kind of puts an interesting twist on the competition discussion is--and then the reverse of that is the discussion about well, you have a monopoly if you have only one provider in the private sector. And so how do we deal with that?

And these are--these are difficult questions. And as you can see, we have different perspectives on that on the committee. I encourage the Fed as it moves forward here, which apparently it is doing to take these kinds of considerations carefully into mind. And hopefully, we'll be able to work this out.

The question I want to address, however, is the one of digital currencies. As you're all aware that this committee right now is dealing with the Libra proposal from Facebook, which is only one of the more recent utilizations of blockchain technology on the internet. But in the context of creating a digital currency. And we have many examples of this technological development on the internet, Bitcoin and many others. But they raised the question as, I understand it, of whether we are moving technologically to a whole different world than the one which we spent this entire hearing discussing. And that that world is digital currency-related technology, which perhaps, are central banks, as well as all of our financial institutions, small banks, and large banks alike, credit card companies, every--every kind of transaction, need to be more focused on.

And I know that I just asked a very huge question and asked you all to--to respond very briefly. And I really mean, perhaps what you could do is respond to me on this, just your--your thoughts about this issue in general, in writing, following the hearing. But am I right, am I correct that we need to start looking at this entire transition to or whether there really is a transition? Is this a--a technological change that we should consider as being transformative in the way that we deal with currency and with financial transactions?

Why don't we just go down the line? Ms. George?

GEORGE: Thank you, Senator. It's a very important issue, I think because it's hard to forecast where this is going. And it's one of the reasons that we study carefully, what does it mean? Because one thing we know is, we've invested heavily in trying to have a banking system that is sound, that serves the economy that serves the American public. And of course, with that has come safety nets, consumer protections, thinking about access to credit, many of those things.

As we look at what disruption may come to the existing framework, I think that's why it's important we study to see how will any of the, those safeguards be disrupted? How will they apply in a new world with different technologies? And I think at this stage requires us to be very cautious and look carefully to make sure that we gain the benefits of innovation, gain the benefits that can come from new technological approaches without undermining I think what has been hard-earned and won safeties for the economy.

CRAPO: Thank you. Anybody else want to comment?

HUNTER: Senator, Mr. Chairman, I--I appreciate the question. We certainly share Ms. Bair's and--and other folks' concern about unregulated and largely unsupervised social media companies getting into setting up digital currencies that could threaten the--the prominence and the value of the U.S. dollar. That said, we've looked at digital currencies or blockchain as a technology through--throughout its--its--its--its development and deployment across the U.S.

And it really is not terribly fit for purpose, when you think about using it as a payment system, it takes an enormous amount of processing power, it's relatively slow, it doesn't sort of process the number of transactions that you need to process, and the speed, and the volume that you need to really serve--serve the country.

I think it's one of the reasons why--I mean, this concept has been around for a long time. You don't really see it being deployed and used a lot for payment system. It's sort of deployed around the edges. It's not really caught on. It's a blockchain is--is a great solution for the register of deeds office where you want records that go back until the beginning of time and you can create lots of information, but it's not terribly fit for purpose in--in the payment space.

CRAPO: All right. Anyone else?

STEEN: I would--I do have some thoughts on that. And I would like to submit them to--

CRAPO: --I'd appreciate that. Yeah.

BAIR: No, I just--I appreciate the question. I think you're right to focus on it and face--something like the Facebook's Libra would take payments completely outside of the banking system. We would--we would lose substantial control. So whether it's technologically feasible or not, I mean, Facebook's pretty smart company. And they've been a lot of time and they seem to think it would. I think the lack of any kind of regulatory structure around that.

I think--you know, and I--I encourage the committee continue looking at that because I--the last thing we want is to lose control of our--our fiat currency. Which is why I think ultimately, central banks, including the Fed need to get ahead of this technology and capture it themselves so that they cannot be disrupted by a--a large non-bank entity like a Facebook.

SELGIN: Yes, I would add, Senator, to that. We've all been talking about the benefits of competition in the payment system. And these digital currencies are part of that potential competition. And they're a particularly important part because they represent some very intriguing innovations, that it's an--it's have not come from government, have come from the private sector. We don't know the full potential benefits that may be had from these technologies.

Ultimately, Mr. Hunter's quite correct that so far, they have not been particularly useful for payments, although people think of them as being used in that connection. They have a lot of disadvantages but I think it's desirable that they too be part of the process.

As for central banks providing digital currencies themselves. Well, it must be said that the paper notes that the Federal Reserve issues are the horse and buggies--

(LAUGHTER)

--of the modern pavement system. And that digital substitutes for these could well be an improvement.

But there once again, we would want the Fed to be competing with private sector providers and not monopolizing the provision of these substitutes. And there's no reason why you could not have some private digital monies that are dollar-based. And we have things that are close to that so far. The main thing is that competition has to be allowed to work itself out amongst parties participating in a--on a level playing field.

CRAPO: Well, thank you, and I appreciate the--these insights. I would welcome any further insights you'd like to share with me on this issue. It seems to me that this is--unless it becomes clear that it's such a cumbersome innovation that it just can't be utilized in the payments system or in the currency systems of the world, it seems to me that this could be a truly a disruptive influence in and I don't say that in a negative sense. I mean, in the context of--of its impact on--on literally currency transactions of all types in the world.

And--and some of those impacts can be very positive impacts, some can be very dangerous impacts, you think of things from eliminating cost to consumer in the system, to expanding opportunity for money laundering and--and all kinds of other different potential impacts of--of the expansion of this new type of innovation. So I'd love your thoughts on it. As we move forward. This is an--obviously another issue that the committee is currently struggling with.

With that, I want to conclude this hearing. Again, I welcome--I thank you for all of your--your input and welcome your further input on this. For senators who wish to submit questions for the record. Those questions are due to the committee by Wednesday, October 2. I'll ask the witnesses if you would all respond to those questions as promptly as you can. We'd appreciate it. And again, thank you for being here. This hearing is adjourned.

Senate Banking, Housing And Urban Affairs Committee Holds Hearing On Impacts Of Data Brokers

June 11, 2019 10:00 A.M.

SPEAKERS:

SEN. MICHAEL D. CRAPO (R-IDAHO), CHAIRMAN

SEN. RICHARD C. SHELBY (R-ALA.)

SEN. PATRICK J. TOOMEY (R-PA.)

SEN. TIM SCOTT (R-S.C.)

SEN. BEN SASSE (R-NEB.)

SEN. TOM COTTON (R-ARK.)

SEN. MIKE ROUNDS (R-S.D.)

SEN. DAVID PERDUE (R-GA.)

SEN. THOM TILLIS (R-N.C.)

SEN. JOHN KENNEDY (R-LA.)

SEN. MARTHA MCSALLY (R-ARIZ.)

SEN. JERRY MORAN (R-KAN.)

SEN. KEVIN CRAMER (R-N.D.)

SEN. SHERROD BROWN (D-OHIO), RANKING MEMBER

SEN. JACK REED (D-R.I.)

SEN. ROBERT MENENDEZ (D-N.J.)

SEN. JON TESTER (D-MONT.)

SEN. MARK WARNER (D-VA.)

SEN. ELIZABETH WARREN (D-MASS.)

SEN. BRIAN SCHATZ (D-HAWAII)

SEN. CHRIS VAN HOLLEN (D-MD.)

SEN. CATHERINE CORTEZ MASTO (D-NEV.)

SEN. DOUG JONES (D-ALA.)

SEN. TINA SMITH (D-MINN.)

SEN. KYRSTEN SINEMA (D-ARIZ.)

[*]CRAPO: This hearing will come to order. Providing testimony to the committee today are experts who have researched and written extensively on big data--Dr. Alicia Cackley, the director of the Financial Markets and Community Investment at the Government Accountability Office and Ms. Pam Dixon, executive director of the World Privacy Forum. We appreciate both of you being here.

As a result of increasingly digital--an increasingly digital economy, more personal information is available to companies and others than ever before. I've been troubled by government agencies and private companies collection of personally identifiable information for a long time. There have been many questions about how individuals or groups of individuals information is collected, with whom it is shared or sold, how it is used and how it is secured. Private companies are collecting, processing, analyzing and sharing massive data on individuals for all kinds of purposes.

Even more troubling is that the vast majority of Americans do not even know what data is being collected, when it's being collected, how it's being collected, by whom and for what purpose. In particularly, data brokers and technology companies including large social media platforms and search engines play a central role in gathering vast amounts of personal information and often without interacting with individuals specifically in the case of data brokers.

In 2013, the GAO issued a report on information resellers which includes data brokers and the need for the consumer privacy framework to reflect changes in technology in the marketplace. The report that the current statutory consumer privacy framework fails to address fully new technologies and the growing marketplace for personal information. The GAO also provided several recommendations to Congress on how to approach the issue to provide consumers with more control over their data.

In 2018--five years later--GAO published a blog summarizing its 2013 report highlighting the continued relevance of the report's findings. The Federal Trade Commission also released a report in 2014 that emphasized the big row of data brokers in the economy. The FTC observed in its report that data brokers collect and store billions of data elements covering nearly every U.S. consumer and that data brokers collect data from numerous sources largely without consumers knowledge.

In her report "The Scoring of America", Pam Dixon discusses predictive consumer scoring across the country--across the economy including the big role that data brokers play. She stresses that today, no protections exist for most consumer scores similar to those that apply to credit scores under the Fair Credit Reporting Act.

Dixon says, "Consumer scores are today where credit scores were in the 1950's. Data brokers, merchants, government entities and others can create or use a consumer score without notice to consumers."

Dr. Cackley has also issued several reports on consumer privacy and technology including a report in September 2013 on information resellers which includes data brokers. She says in her report that the current consumer privacy framework does not fully address new technologies and the vastly increased marketplace for personal information. She also discusses potential gaps in current federal law including the Fair Credit Reporting Act.

The Banking Committee has been examining the data issue in both the private and public sectors from regulators to financial companies, to other companies who gather vast amounts of personal information on individuals or groups of individuals to see what can be done through legislation, regulation, or by instituting best practices.

Enacted in 1970, the Fair Credit Reporting Act is a law in the Banking Committee's jurisdiction which aims to promote the accuracy, fairness, and privacy of consumer information contained in the files of consumer reporting agencies. Given the exponential growth and use of data since that time, the rise of entities that appear to serve a similar function as the original credit reporting agencies, it's worth examining how the Fair Credit Reporting Act should work in a digital economy.

During today's hearing, I look forward to hearing more about the structure and practices of the data broker industry and technology companies such as large social media platforms, how data broker--the data broker industry has evolved within the development of new technologies and their interaction with technological--technology companies, what information these entities collect, how it is collected, and whom it is shared with, and for what purposes. What gaps exist in federal privacy law and what changes to federal law should be considered to give individuals real control over their data.

I appreciate each of you joining us today and look forward to getting some further information about these questions. Senator Brown?

BROWN: Thank you, Mr. Chairman. I appreciate your continuing these important bipartisan efforts to protect Americans since it's sensitive personal information. We're looking today at a shadow injury known as data brokers. Most of us--most of you probably haven't heard of these companies. The biggest ones include names like Axiom, Encore Logic, and Spokio, and Zoom Info, and maybe one you've heard of called Oracle.

According to some estimates, 4,000 of these companies collect and sell private information. But stunningly--and I'm not sure I've ever used that word in this committee--stunningly, not one of them has been willing to show up and speak in front of this committee today. Not one.

These companies expected--expect to be trusted with the most personal and private information you could imagine about a--about millions and millions of Americans. They're not even willing to show up and explain how their industry works. Some define this as cowardice. It's hard to disagree with that. I think it tells you all you need to know about how much they want their own faces and names associated with that industry.

As Mache Zagorsky (PH) told us in our last hearing, "The daily activities of most Americans are now tracked and permanently recorded by automated systems at Google or Facebook." Most of that private activity isn't useful without data that anchors it to the real world. Facebook, Google, Amazon want to know where you're using your credit cards, where you buy your brand name appliances, if you're recently divorced, how big your life insurance policy is--the kind of data that big tech gets from data brokers.

They then combine it with your social media activity to feed into their algorithms. You might've noticed it seems like every product or service you buy comes with a survey or a warning card that asks for--asks for strangely personal information. Why are all these non-tech companies so interested in your data?

It's simple. Data brokers will pay these companies for any of your personal information they can get their hands on, so they can turn around and sell it to the--to Silicon Valley. It's hard for ordinary consumers to have any power when unbeknownst to them, they're actually--they are actually the product bought and sold.

It reminds me of a time when corporations that had no business being in the lending industry decided to start making loans and selling them off to Wall Street. We know what happened. Manufacturers or car companies decided that consumer credit would be a great way to boost their profits. When big banks and big tech are willing to pay for something, everyone else will find a way to sell it to them often with devastating results.

For example, Amazon's undermining retailers and manufacturing across the country through NI competitive practices. The same time it scoops up information from the very businesses it's pushing out of the market. There's Facebook almost singlehandedly undermining the profitability of newspapers across the country. It also gobbles up personal information.

The New York Times allows data brokers to collect from its leaders. Just like in the financial crisis, a group of shadowy players sits at the center of the market exercising enormous influence over consumers in the economy while facing little or no rules at all. Then they don't share up.

Jeremy Crapo and I are committing to shining a light on these companies to keep an unregulated data economy from spiraling out of control.

Yesterday it was reported a Department of Homeland Security contractor allowed unauthorized access to photos of travelers and their license plates to be exposed to potential identity thieves. One of the principal differences between the two political parties in this town is the suspicion that democrats have of private power and the suspicion republicans typically have of government power. I think you're seeing two parties come together on our suspicion of what these data brokers are doing.

The chairman and I agree that protecting sensitive information like this is timely and important. I look forward to the witness's testimony. Thanks.

CRAPO: Thank you, Senator Brown and I appreciate our partnership on this issue. We will go in the order I introduced you. And Dr. Cackley, you may begin. But before you do, let me just remind both of you that we would like you to keep your initial remarks to five minutes, so that we can have plenty of time for the senators to engage with you. Dr. Cackley?

CACKLEY: Thank you, Chairman Crapo, Ranking Member Brown and members of the committee. I'm pleased to be here today to discuss GAO's work on consumer privacy and information resellers also known as data brokers. My remarks are primarily based on our September 2013 report on privacy--privacy issues related to information resellers, as well as more recent work on internet privacy, data protection, facial recognition, and financial technology.

My statement will focus on two main issues--the lack of an overarching federal privacy law and gaps that exist in the current consumer privacy framework. No overarching federal privacy law governs the collection, use and sale of personal information among private sector companies including information resellers.

There are also no federal laws designed specifically to address all the products sold and information maintained by information resellers. Instead, federal privacy laws covering the private sector are narrowly tailored to specific purposes, situations, types of information and/or entities such as data related to financial transactions, personal health and eligibility for credit.

For example, the Fair Credit Reporting Act requires that sensitive consumer information be protected and restricts how it is shared. But the law only applies to information used to determine eligibility for things like credit, insurance and employment.

Similarly, the Gramm Leach Bliley Act restricts how certain financial information is shared, but it only applies to entities that fall under the law specific definition of a financial institution. Other privacy statutes address other specific circumstances, but there is no federal statute that comprehensively addresses privacy issues in the private sector.

GAO has stated previously that gaps exist in the U.S consumer privacy framework. We've reported that federal law provides consumers with limited ability to access, control and correct their personal data--particularly data used for marketing purposes.

Similarly, individuals generally cannot prevent their personal information from being collected, used and shared. Yet information that resellers collect and share for marketing purposes can be very personal or sensitive. For example, it can include information about physical and mental health, income and assets, political affiliations, and sexual habits, and orientation.

Another area where there are gaps in the consumer privacy framework is with respect to new technologies. For example, federal law does not address expressly when companies can use facial recognition technology to identify or track individuals, nor does it address when consumer knowledge or consent should be required for its use.

Similarly, no federal privacy law explicitly addresses the full range of practices for tracking or collecting data from consumers online activity, or the application software from mobile devices. And the rise of financial services technologies--known as FinTech--raises new privacy concerns. For example, because new sources of personal data are being used to determine credit worthiness.

In summary, new markets and technologies have vastly changed the amount of personal information private companies collect and how they use it. But our current privacy framework does not fully address these changes. Laws protecting privacy interests are tailored to specific sectors and uses. And consumers have little control over how their information is collected, used and shared with third parties for marketing purposes.

As a result, the current privacy framework warrants reconsideration by Congress in relation to consumer interests, new technologies and other issues. Chairman Crapo, Ranking Member Brown, and members of the committee, this concludes my statement. I would be pleased to answer any questions you may have.

CRAPO: Thank you. Ms. Dixon?

DIXON: Thank you, Chairman Crapo, Ranking Member Brown, and members of the committee. Thank you for your invitation and for the opportunity to talk about something very, very meaningful today--the Fair Credit Reporting Act, data brokers and privacy.

Fifty years ago, this committee struck a blow for consumers, for transparency and for fairness when it passed the Fair Credit Reporting Act. This committee talked with stakeholders. They found best practices and before the Hugh--the famous Hugh Report came out--the committee report that defined what became fair information practices--this committee created the Fair Credit Reporting Act.

It was and still is the most important American privacy law that we have. But it's not as important as it was. There are three reasons why.

First, credit scores and other scores are being sold and used in consumers lives and these are unregulated.

Second, the technology of prediction--what can be called predictive analytics otherwise known as AI and machine learning. This technology--and suite of technologies--has advanced profoundly and especially in the last 3-4 years. New kinds of predictabilities have come forth and we have new levels of accuracy in prediction, so that what used to be the accuracy of the credit score now is also the accuracy of an unregulated credit score. And this introduces new problems for consumers.

Third, these scores are created without due process for consumers. How on earth do we deal with this?

This is why Congress must expand the Fair Credit Reporting Act to regulate currently unregulated scores especially in the financial sector that are being used in meaningful ways in consumers lives.

We have other solutions to discuss and other issues to discuss. I look forward to your questions. Thank you.

CRAPO: Thank you very much, Ms. Dixon. I'd like to ask each of you to answer my first three questions and then I want to get into more discussion. But I would like you--if you possibly can--to limit your answers to yes or no answers to the first three. I know you'll be tempted to elaborate, but I'll give you that chance.

First, do you agree that data brokers collect and process vast amounts of personal information on nearly every American to the extent that they hold more information about individuals than the U.S. government, or traditional credit, and bureaus?

CACKLEY: Yes.

DIXON: Yes.

CRAPO: Second, do you both agree that most Americans have no knowledge of these activities and in most cases no rights to access, correct, or control the information collected about them?

DIXON: Yes.

CACKLEY: Yes.

CRAPO: And then, third, can certain processing and uses of this information have significant impacts on their financial lives?

CACKLEY: Yes.

DIXON: Yes, absolutely.

CRAPO: All right, now we'll get to where you can elaborate.

(LAUGHTER)

You have both authored reports as the FTC in 2014 that highlighted the gaps in the Fair Credit Reporting Act and other privacy laws. You've both testified about that in your introductory remarks.

These gaps allow data brokers to evade certain requirements that shouldn't be implied--imposed on them. What are the steps that we can take? You indicated Ms. Dixon that we need to expand the Fair Credit Reporting Act and you essentially said the same thing, Dr. Cackley. But what specifically does this committee need to do with regard to that?

DIXON: Thank you. In regards to the Fair Credit Reporting Act, it--it--I think very small changes would be very meaningful. Let me give you an example. Right now, as you know--as you well know, the Fair Credit Reporting Act in regards to credit scores applies to individuals. So, when we are, you know, that is regulated the--at the individual level.

However, if you look at the new forms of credit scores that are available, they are scored at the household level where the Fair Credit Reporting Act does not apply. So, you take a zip plus four and you--you score a household, and give them let's say a score of 720. The household has a very accurate score of 720, then that becomes an unregulated form of credit score. And, you now, these scores were quasi-accurate. That's changed.

CRAPO: Thank you. Dr. Cackley?

CACKLEY: The Fair Credit Reporting Act has a--a certain number of--of elements to it that are--that are very helpful. It gives consumers access, control, the ability to correct information and--and safeguards privacy. But it only applies for certain--in certain situations for eligibility decisions. It would be possible to think about looking at a broader set of personal, sensitive information that--that the Fair Credit Reporting Act could cover that would give consumers more of those things--access control, ability to correct--over more sensitive--personal sensitive information than is currently available.

CRAPO: All right. And--and I'm going to use the term--well, Ms. Dixon you used--you used the term "unregulated credit scores." There is a set of data that is collected about individuals and as you indicate, households. And this data is turned into some kind of an analysis that allows those who use the data to influence and manipulate individuals in--in the marketplace.

Historically--as you've both indicated--the Fair Credit Reporting Act has focused primarily on credit bureaus. But the scope of who is collecting this data, and how it is being used has exploded as you've both also discussed. The question I have is, isn't this unregulated score that we're talking about that is created for people and then managed by AI--isn't that impacting people's credit? Isn't it impacting their financial decisions? Isn't it significantly focused on that type of influence and manipulation of individuals?

CACKLEY: I--I think it--it certainly can be. The--the scores can--may not be credit scores, but they may apply to decisions that companies are making about what kinds of products they offer people, at what price they offer things based on a score that the consumer doesn't necessarily see and can't--can't even tell if it's correct or can't make any--any attempt to--to approve that score if they don't even know it exists.

CRAPO: And to influence them to make such a transaction, yeah. I'll let you go ahead, Ms. Dixon. I'm running out of time here, but go ahead please.

DIXON: Thank you. It's--we call any score that is not regulated by the Federal Credit Reporting Act consumer scores and we define that. It's in the written testimony. Consumer scores are quite dangerous when they're used in eligibility circumstances.

So, for example, the--the line between a lead generation which is allowable. You don't have to pull a credit score to--to create a lead generation for a marketing product or a financial product. However, if you are just maybe marketing a financial product and you have something that is equivalent in accuracy to a credit score, all the sudden this changes the equation. There's--there's not even a micrometer in between what a, you know, a regulation would be and a non-regulated score.

So, if you have essentially something that looks like a credit score, and that acts like a credit score, and is being used like a credit score, well it's the same thing as a duck. If it quacks, it's a duck. So, I think we have to look at the financial products that are being marketed with quasi credit scores very closely. That's of high concern, but there's other categories.

In the scoring of America, we identified literally hundreds of types of scores. Consumer lifetime value scores where consumers are segmented according to how valuable they are in terms of their purchasing power. There's frailty scores which is more of a medical score. But the scores abound and the concern I have is when people lose opportunities that are meaningful in their lives. For example, scores that are used in eligibility circumstances not described by the Fair Credit Reporting Act such as admissions to colleges and whatnot.

Imagine having a wonderful high school background and working very hard to achieve the American dream. And then, all of a sudden, some score says that you won't be as qualified as a candidate having nothing to do with your academic achievements, but just somehow with maybe the neighborhood you grew up in. I find this disturbing.

CRAPO: Agreed. Senator Brown?

BROWN: Thank you, Mr. Chairman. Now Ms. Dixon, you noted that tens of thousands of consumers' scores affecting millions and millions of consumers are used to predict--are used to predict our behaviors or secrets you said. Are you--are you surprised that I mean, Chairman Crapo was not able--nor were we able to bring in data brokers to speak and testify? Are you surprised they weren't willing to testify about their business practices before this Committee today?

DIXON: Actually, I am surprised and I'm actually--I--I wish they were here and I wish the credit bureaus were here as well because we need to have good industries step forward and to give us their best practices that they use. If there's no good industry to step forward with best practices, then this committee cannot rearticulate what it did 50 years ago.

BROWN: Well--

DIXON: And I don't understand why these industries are not willing to discuss what's happening. And I--

BROWN: I think--

DIXON: --also don't understand why we can't see our scores. Why?

BROWN: I am not sure that they didn't show up. I guess I'd like to--I'm not sure I've done this anymore before either. I'd like to ask anybody in the room that represents the data brokers to raise their hand. Lobbyists? Lawyers? People paid by the data broker industry? Any of you here? Any of you here that want to raise your hand I guess is what I should say.

(LAUGHTER)

Okay. I--I--and if you are, I mean, I--I will give you an opportunity of a lifetime if you are. We'll set up a different chair. And you can set up next to Ms. Dixon and Dr. Cackley. Would you?

Okay, all right. I guess no surprise there, Mr. Chairman and that--that does illustrate how as I--I know they're watching. I mean, this is really important to their industry. It's very important to their bottom line whether they're watching here or they're watching livestream by, but we'll move on.

Ms. Dixon, it seems that data predictions create a vicious cycle where the predictions end up often dictating the outcomes. For example, could people who've been systematically targeted by predatory lenders which have lower--having lower credit scores therefore, be likely only to see advertisements for other predatory financial products--is that--I assume that happens. Are there other examples you can think of quickly?

DIXON: Yes, the predatory example is one we get phone calls about in our office from people who received advertisements for financial products and they didn't understand that they could've gone out on the market and affirmatively looked for the best offer. So, these predatory marketing devices based on unregulated scores are very significant.

Other significant scores are scores that predict repayment of debt. So, for example, it is the poorest consumers who are targeted the most for debt repayment--all sorts of things like this. The consumer lifetime value scores impact how well you're treated by businesses by how long you're standing in line.

But the most meaningful circumstances that I can think of is when kids are applying to schools and they are getting scores that dictate whether or not they're going to be accepted to a school based not on their academics, but based on all of these other things like a pseudo credit score, like how--what neighborhood they grew up in. There are neighborhood risk scores which are the modern-day redlining. And I find them deeply objectionable because if we are going to be scored by where we live, how have we advanced and how have all the laws that have been meant to protect from such things--how are they operating if this is still happening today?

BROWN: So, companies--thank you for that. Companies that particularly--an analogy to redlining--banking redlining, insurance redlining, these companies redlining's--if companies--are you worried that companies would offer discounts for products and services in exchange for sensitive data which would lead you--sort of implied this would lead to a two-tiered system where the wealthy can afford privacy and everyone else will have to sacrifice sensitive information to get access to basic internet services?

DIXON: That's certainly part of it. I think it goes even broad--more broadly than that. One of the big issues is that you get locked into a big filter bubble of sorts--a marketing bubble and it's not that people mean to get locked into these. But if you are receiving offers--especially for financial tools and services and--and a consumer does not go outside of the offers they receive, they can pay more for autos. They can pay more for products. They can pay more for example, a TV--simple things. Simple things, but if you are a consumer on a fixed income, a television that costs $2,000 instead of 200 makes a meaningful difference in a person's life. That's what worries me the most.

BROWN: There's a--there's a--one follow-up. Not a question, but just comment, Mr. Chairman. Thanks for--for your forbearance. I--and the whole idea of--that--that people prey on people that are less able to fight back. Yesterday, I was in Des Moines--not running for President, but in Des Moines.

(LAUGHTER)

And I--I was--I was at a manufactured house--manufactured housing neighborhood. And a large hedge fund from--from Salt Lake City has begun to buy up manufacturing housing neighborhoods. There are six of them in the state. There are a number of them in Iowa. They're in a half dozen states at least.

They come and they buy these. People have paid 50, or 60, or 70,000 for their manufactured home. They pay $200-300 for the--for the rent when the land in these hedge funds is raising rents over a period of about a year--year and a half up to 70 percent and people have nowhere to turn. And it's just--it's like these companies out there are just looking. "Where--where can we come in, extract the most money at the lowest cost against people that have the most--have the least ability to fight back without political connections?" And it's just happening across our economy. Thank you.

CRAPO: Thank you, Senator Brown. Senator Scott?

SCOTT: Thank you, Mr. Chairman. I will note that some people go to Des Moines not to run for president, but perhaps vice president.

(LAUGHTER)

Back over here. So--

(LAUGHTER)

I apologize. I meant--

BROWN: Mr. Chairman, Senator Scott's a smart guy, but that was not the smartest thing he ever said.

(LAUGHTER)

SCOTT: Senator Brown, I realize you don't actually run for vice president by the number of votes you get--

(LAUGHTER)

--but I think there is a process by which people say they are qualified to do things like ask Ms. Dixon a question.

So, one of the--your comments that you made sounded--I spent about 25 years in the insurance industry. So, one of the comments you made sounded a little bit like redlining. And I'd love for you to unpack that a little bit, but just to make sure I heard you. So, an unregulated--in unregulated ways, credit scores that consumers themselves don't know about that consumers haven't seen, heard or contributed to are being used in ways that will impact their financial well-being to include perhaps even the likelihood of jobs that they may or may not be qualified for.

That to me, sounds fairly nefarious, but it sounds a whole lot like redlining. Can you unpack, if that's not what you meant please clarify what you did mean and if it did--if it is what you meant, please drill down a little bit, so that we can have a little more clarity to what you're talking about?

DIXON: Thank you. It's a really complex issue. And in the scoring of America and in my--in my written testimony, I have articulated more fully with footnotes, so.

SCOTT: We have that part, but.
