I believe that same concept--data portability--ought to be brought into the data economy, so that if you are not liking how you're being treated I think about it mostly in the social media context. But there are a variety of areas in the credit scoring areas as well where, you know, if we had that knowledge of what data was being collected, what it's worth--and then, if you didn't like the way Facebook was treating you or some other enterprise, you were easily able to move your--your--all of your data in one swipe to--to a new co or a new platform. I think you could bring some additional competitive practices to--to the area.

In these last couple of seconds, data evaluation, data knowledge, and data portability--ideas, comments, suggestions?

DIXON: I really like the idea of data interoperability's, so that there's more freedom.

WARNER: With portability you've got to have interoperability or it doesn't--

DIXON: Yes, but it's--I think it's going to be something that will end up working out in time, but it should be a good priority.

CACKLEY: So, this isn't something that we've looked at specifically. But I think that to the degree that you're talking about, comprehensive legislation that really covers all of the different platforms and--and parties, then--then that kind of interoperability would--would--would be part of it.

WARNER: We'd like to share with both of you some of the work we've been doing and I think there's a--

CACKLEY: Yeah.

WARNER: --could be broad-based bipartisan support. Thank you, Mr. Chairman.

CRAPO: Thank you. Senator Kennedy?

KENNEDY: Thank you, Mr. Chairman. If I go on the internet, and I search, and I look at social media, and I buy something on Amazon let's say, who--I mean, my--my actions--my behavior is recorded. We call it data. Who owns it?

DIXON: I have a whitepaper I'm going to send to you. We've spent a lot of time thinking about this issue. So, the issue of data ownership is quite difficult to parse. But let me give you my best shot--

KENNEDY: Yes, ma'am.

DIXON: --and let's have a discussion.

KENNEDY: If--if--well--

DIXON: So--

KENNEDY: --I'd like to have a discussion, but first I'd like to have an answer.

DIXON: Here's the answer. I view data as--in our current data ecosystems--as a common pool resource. I think a lot of different entities can lay claim to that data. However, no one gets to own it. And--well, in some cases--

KENNEDY: You don't think that I own my data?

DIXON: --you can. It depends on where you've used it and where it is. I think there's some--

KENNEDY: Not on how much you--

DIXON: Yeah.

CACKLEY: I don't think there is a--an answer to--to who owns that--your data when once you've--you've taken an action especially in--in some ways interacted with a--with another company.

KENNEDY: Well let's suppose that Congress passed a law that said the consumer owns his data and he or she can knowingly license it. What would be wrong with that?

CACKLEY: I--I don't think there--there be anything wrong with it. I think it would--it would have impact on--on who could then collect that your data or whether data could be collected.

KENNEDY: No, I can--I can--I could license my data knowingly.

CACKLEY: Right.

KENNEDY: Now, what--what--in--in--in terms of knowingly licensing my data that I own, what sort of disclosures should a social media company for example make to me in terms of how it's going to use my data? Right now, they make disclosures but--but they're--there--they're--they don't inform the consumer. I've said before, some of those things are seven, eight, nine, ten pages written by lawyers. You could hide a dead body in them and nobody would find them--find the body, I mean nobody reads them. That's not knowing consent. What--what does a social media company have to tell me in order for me to know what they're doing?

DIXON: May I offer an example from the--the medical field? So under--under HIPAA, there are very meaningful mechanisms prior to a consumer agreeing to release their information outside of the protection of HIPPA. However, one of the concerns that's come up with this is that it's become very, very easy for consumers patients to "donate their data." And what's happened is that people have donated their data and taken it out of the protections of HIPPA without meaningful consent.

KENNEDY: I'm not--I'm not trying to be rude, I'm trying to get answers. Here's my question. If I own my data and I license it, I need to understand what license it--licensing it means. What needs to be disclosed to me?

DIXON: My understanding, looking at other fields because this is not something I have studied at length. My understanding is that the--that is a serious agreement and it would require massive disclosures. I think you could almost put a graveyard in that disclosure, you know, compared to--

KENNEDY: And you don't--you don't think it's possible to--to write a disclosure that the consumer would understand. Is that what you imply?

DIXON: In this area, I'd have to really look at that--that--again, this is not an area of research for me but I--I--

KENNEDY: What do you think (INAUDIBLE)?

CACKLEY: I think it--it would be--it would be very complicated. So it is not an area that we've looked at either but--but just in--if--if Congress were to pass a law that allowed consumers to license their own data, that would just create a large amount of--of regulations to go along with that.

KENNEDY: So you both think that we should just allow companies to do what they want with our data, that this is a--this is a problem this problem is impossible to solve?

CACKLEY: No, no, and I don't think I meant that at all. I just meant that it would--it would have to be worked through, it--it's not an easy fix. It's--it's--

KENNEDY: No, I don't think an easy fix is around here.

DIXON: And I don't mean that either. I--I believe that we should have rules of the road and we should have agreed upon rules on what--

KENNEDY: That--that's--I agree with that too and--and everybody--I mean, we've had a lot of interesting discussions about this but--but no offense to you two, but then the experts never offer a solution. So to me, the solution is consumer owns his data, you can license it, the licensing has to be knowing and--and intentional. You can move your data, portability should--should be an option. I can change my mind about licensing it and--and companies will adapt to that, they'll have no choice. Thank you, Mr. chairman.

CRAPO: Senator Menendez.

MENENDEZ: Thank you Mr. Chairman. I had the same concerns as Senator Kennedy because we seem to be living and in age of data breaches. Just last week, we learned of a breach concerning a medical billing company, America Medical Coalition Agency that may have exposed the personal financial and even medical data of 20 million patients who are customers of Quest Diagnostics and LabCorp.

So let me ask you, Ms. Dixon, people are rightly concerned that some of their personal data is now exposed and could be used against them. Can data brokers legally compile aggregate or sell data that has been acquired through an illegal hack?

DIXON: I haven't, I am not an attorney. So I think that's a question that an attorney could better answer you. But my first best guess is I don't think you can use improperly inferme--information that has been disclosed in an unauthorized manner for your own business purposes. That seems like that would be really out of balance.

MENENDEZ: Dr. Cackley, do you have any idea?

CACKLEY: I don't know the answer but I can certainly find out.

MENENDEZ: Yeah, well I appreciate that. Should people be concerned the data not otherwise covered by HIPAA is ending up in the hands of data brokers even in the absence of a hack? Are billing companies like America Medical Coalition Agencies selling non-HIPAA data to brokers?

DIXON: This is an ongoing area of grave concern for us. There are actual scores of health data. There's a frailty score that can predict very closely how sick you are and when you might possibly die. I think that there are all sorts of scores and products so related to--

MENENDEZ: Not sure I want to check on that data myself but--

DIXON: Yeah me either. But--but--

MENENDEZ: But that's--that's pretty frightening, isn't it?

DIXON: It is and health--you know, health data that is not covered under HIPAA is become an increasing area so--

MENENDEZ: Let me ask you this. When hackers gained access to non-HIPAA data like in the Quest data breach, can data brokers apply machine learning to these data points to infer or reconstruct sensitive HIPPA protected medical data?

DIXON: I actually don't think that they need to acquire unauthorized data in order to do that. They can just look at our purchase histories and get an awful lot of data about us. But in terms of what's happening with this entire area, the data breaches of medical data actually can lead to forms of identity theft and medical identity theft that are very, very difficult to cure and you can have extremely meaningful consequences in people's life.

MENENDEZ: Let me ask you then. HIPAA's nearly 25 years old and in 2009, high tech provided updates which were concerning health information technology, but I'm still concerned that we're playing catch-up when it comes to protecting patients. And, you know, of all the information that should be private and privileged to you, your health standing should be extraordinary. There are all types of consequences in that in employment, in discrimination and a whole host of things. Are there gaps in HIPAA and other data security laws that need to be addressed to better protect people today in this 21st century threat? What's coordination is missing between existing legal protections?

DIXON: I--I do think there's gaps and the biggest gaps that exist right now are the gaps that exist between the sectoral protections. And I don't think the answer is to just rip out the sector protections that exist such as a Fair Credit Reporting Act or HIPAA or Sarbanes-Oxley etc, but to find a way to fill those gaps in. For example, victims of medical identity theft can use their Fair Credit Reporting Act rights to get their financial information corrected, but under HIPAA they are--it is--it's not possible for them because it doesn't exist in this statute.

It's not possible for them to get a deletion similar to the FCRA in their health files so they could actually carry around inaccurate information which can really have an impact on their treatment and insurance costs and there's not a solution yet. So this is the kind of gap we need to address.

MENENDEZ: Lastly there's one breach that compromises the personal information of 20 million pra--patients, that's pretty troubling. One data broker has data on 300 million consumers. We're still reeling from the Equifax breach which affected 145.5 million consumers. If the information of 300 million consumers were to be compromised, we might start calling for private information, public information because at the end of the day, that's the result of it.

What's the ramifications for consumer if a data broker is breached and should we hold them to a higher standard of security especially because their volume is so consequential?

DIXON: Data broker breaches are very significant. So my--my assessment of this is that the--the various state data breach laws are doing a pretty good job especially in some cases where the data breach law is quite strong in forcing disclosures and--and notices but I think we need to do more to ensure that all of the information held that is sensitive and health related etc, is duly notified to the consumer.

The problem with the data brokers is what they will say is, oh wait, wait, we don't have a direct relationship with the consumers, we can't notify them. And I think that is a gap that needs to be resolved. Now, the state of Vermont has resolved that gap.

MENENDEZ: They could--they could--they could reach back to the entity that provided them the data in the first place and they could notify. Could they not?

DIXON: I believe that that could happen and it has happened--

MENENDEZ: I just think--I just think they should be held to a higher standard of security because the consequences of incredible numbers of Americans that are subject to having their privacy breached and their healthcare breached is just beyond acceptance. Thank you, Mr. chairman.

CRAPO: Thank you. Senator Rounds.

ROUNDS: Thank you, Mr. Chairman, and thank you for holding this--this hearing today. I--I--I'd like to see if I--in--in listening to this, if I've picked up the grasp of some of the challenges we have here. It would appear to me that--that we're talking about first of all the question of the security of the data that's actually being collected. Second of all, it appears that we're questioning whether or not, there is an appropriate way for individual consumers or individuals to actually find out and to have access to what these organizations, these non-regulated organizations actually have.

And Finally, that this appears that may very well be a workaround with regard to the information that's being collected and then disseminated from what a regulated entity would have. In a nutshell, are those the three areas and would there be other areas that you would also identify? I would ask each of you for your thoughts.

CACKLEY: Those are certainly three of the--of the main points that have come up today. I think the oth--other piece that we haven't touched on maybe as much is outside of--of the--the data brokers themselves. There are--there are other technologies where--where privacy issues that have to do with--with, you know, mobile devices, with facial recognition technology, we did mention that, with financial technology that are--that are also areas of concern that--that are--fall outside potentially the--the protections of FCRA in particular.

ROUNDS: The use of machine learning and artificial intelligence in this process. Okay, miss Dixon.

DIXON: So my focus has really never been on the technologies as an endpoint. My focus has always been on okay, so we have technological processes that are going to continue through time but what does that actually mean in practice that I've always looked at the practice? So your--your assessment of where the sticking points are is accurate. The thing I would add is this.

I think it's going to become as we move forward and prediction gets cheaper, I think prediction is going to be coming to a mobile phone near us like ours, and I think we have to be very cautious about looking at categories of technologies and label--labeling them as bad. Similarly, in industry, I think we have to be very careful and say okay, what are the practices that we want to go after here and want to address because they're harming consumers? And if we can do that in a truly multifactorial way, I think that will be helpful.

Wherever these practices exist, wherever they are, we need to be addressing them because they're meaningful and they have impact.

ROUNDS: There's a difference between the way that we have looked at data and data collection and privacy in the United States versus the way that it's been done in some other parts of the world. Here, we follow and we use Gramm-Leach-Bliley within the United States but in Europe they take a different approach, the GDPR which seeks to really achieve a--a different and more comprehensive approach but would be rather challenging.

Can you share with me the thought process or your analysis of the differences or the advantages one versus the other between the way that we handle it today in the United States versus what they have--what they're doing in Europe with the GDPR in its current form?

CACKLEY: So we haven't looked at GDPR directly yet but I can say that that there are definitely some elements of GDPR that are--are already embodied in the--the fair information practices principles that--that are the basis of--of some of our privacy regulation already. There are other pieces that--that--that are not and--and one of the main ones I would say is the right to be forgotten which is a part of GDPR that--that really doesn't--it isn't encompassed in--in anything here.

ROUNDS: (INAUDIBLE) Ms. Dixon.

DIXON: Sorry. The GDPR, the--as you know it's--it--it was built on the EU 9546. So it's--it's--it has a lot of bureaucratic history behind it. If you look at what they were trying to do in all the derogations and whatnot, it's a really complex and thoughtful structure. I think that it does provide for baseline privacy protections, but they don't have the sectoral system and they don't have government privacy. So I think there is one thing I'll say, in--in--in our country the Privacy Act is very effective in--in regulating certain aspects of government information collection, they don't have anything like that.

ROUNDS: Thank you and I see my time has expired, Mr. chairman. Thank you both of you for your--for your answers today and Mr. chairman once again, thank you for the--the opportunity here today with the--this--this hearing on this very important topic.

CRAPO: Thank You senator Rounds. Senator Sinema.

SINEMA: Thank you Mr. chairman and--and thank you to our witnesses for being here today. At the committee's last hearing on privacy, I spoke about the importance of privacy to Arizonans. We are practical people who want the modern conveniences that technology brings but we value our privacy. So I'm committed to making sure that Arizonans know how our data is being used so that we can make informed decisions.

Arizonans also don't like assumptions being made about us or how we choose to live our lives particularly if some of those assumptions are wrong, which is why current privacy and consumer scoring laws concern both me and many Arizonans. In 2013, the FTC competed and published a 10-year congressionally mandated study on the accuracy of credit reports. The FTC found that one in five consumers had an error on at least one of their three credit reports.

So Ms. Dixon, first thank you for being here. I want you to talk quickly about credit scores as a starting point and what happens if you and I were one of those consumers. How drastically could an error in a credit report negatively affect an Arizonans credit score?

DIXON: Yes. That--that effect would be profound. So for example, for victims of identity theft, if someone has run up your credit and it's not actually your error, you could be seen as not making your payments, etc., and you can literally move from a 780 score to a 620 in very short order, only takes about a month. And then what you have is a situation where if you are about to buy a home and this is--these are from the calls we get. This isn't just a hypothesis here- the--the home you're about to buy all of a sudden, you can't qualify for a mortgage you because of identity theft. So yes, any error from any source that's in your credit report, it is a piece of serious business.

SINEMA: So Ms. Dixon, you said this could potentially prevent an Arizonian from buying a home. Would it also get in the way of financing an education or starting a small business or expanding one's business?

DIXON: Absolutely.

SINEMA: Wow, that's really troubling. Under the Fair Credit Reporting Act, if an Arizonan thinks his or her credit report or score's inaccurate, they can appeal it with the bureau, is that correct? And if so, how?

DIXON: Yes, there is a--there is a very specific procedure outlined in law where the--the bureaus must respond and there is a series of steps that they can take and both the--the Federal Trade Commission and the CFPB have numerous help and hotlines to help everyone through and the state AG's also do as well but they're--they're very well documented recourses for consumers in this situation.

SINEMA: Well that's good. So we've established it's important to have an accurate credit score and there's a process to appeal it and fix it. But increasingly, businesses are using so called consumer scores that rank, rate, and segment consumers based on public private and government data that's packaged and sold by data brokers and others. So sometimes, as public data is inaccurate, it's often outdated or it could be incomplete. So are all consumer scores made available to consumers just like credit scores are?

DIXON: Actually, almost none of them are. In fact, I've had almost no success despite trying to get consumer scores and asking companies for my consumer score. It is almost impossible to get them.

SINEMA: But then how would an Arizonan know if his or her consumer score was inaccurate if they can't get access to it?

DIXON: That's the same question I have. They would not know.

SINEMA: Well, so let's say that an Arizonan were able to find out that his or her consumer score is inaccurate. Are all consumer scores covered under the FCRA so that there's a similar appeals process to resolve inaccuracies?

DIXON: No consumer scores are that are unregulated are currently covered under the FCRA unless it is a formal credit score as articulated by the FCRA and it used in an eligibility circumstance and it's not covered.

SINEMA: Well, that's very concerning but thank you for sharing that information with us. Mr. Chairman and ranking member Brown, it's clear that we have a lot of work to do here. We've got to update our privacy laws to reflect new trends that are occurring in both business and technology to make sure that Americans have the right to correct their record, whether it's their credit score or their consumer score on who they are, how they live their lives and what mistakes or inaccuracies that might be over occurring in their lives.

So I thank you for being here our witnesses and I look forward to working with the committee on this and Mr. chairman, I yield back.

CRAPO: Thank you. That concludes the first round but Senator--Senator Brown and I would like to do a second round and you're welcome to join in with us senators if you would like.

There's so many questions. One of them I want to get back to which has been brought up by several senators is this notion of the tension between doing a comprehensive bill like the GDPR in Europe or a sectoral approach like we do in the United States, and I think we all can understand there's sort of a push and a pull on both sides of that question.

It seems to me though that we don't have a choice at least at a basic level to deal with all data collection in the same way. I think one of you mentioned earlier that it's all blending. It used to be that we could clearly distinguish what a credit bureau did and the credit report that a credit bureau prepared. Now, we have massive amounts. I think Senator Brown referenced the 4,000 number. But I don't even know what the number is of entities that are collecting data.

My understanding is that the apps on my iPhone, many of them collect data even when I'm not using them to report further to others about whatever it is, data that's not even often related to the app. And it seems to me that all of that data is in one way or another not just blending, but being utilized for many, many different purposes. One of which is credit, one of which is retail sales one of which is college applications, one of it is mortgages. I mean the list can go on and on and on.

So I guess I'd like to have each of you just briefly, because I have got some more questions but briefly indicate. Do you believe that--that's--that at some basic point, the United States needs to have a comprehensive set of standards and requirements that would cover some basics like when data is being collected, who's collecting it, whether there's an opt-in or an opt-out, what rights to manage or even remove if once data exists?

CACKLEY: Yes, I think that's--that is where we are right now is--is that the sectoral approach is--it leaves too many gaps and a comprehensive framework. Maybe not completely changing to--to only a comprehensive framework. You could--you could merge the two in some ways but a comprehensive framework that gives a basic privacy rights and--and abilities for consumers to know what their data is and--and how to correct it, how to control it is--is definitely something that needs to be--to be addressed.

CRAPO: Thank you. Ms. Dixon.

DIXON: Let me share with you that I've been seeking an answer to the question you just asked for about 27 years. So here's what I've come up with and it's just--it's my opinion. What if the sectoral system was a feature, not a bug born from thoughtful deliberation about very focused issue areas with a lot of buy-in? What if we have not been able to pass comprehensive legislation because our system requires more buy-in than other systems?

These are just the hypotheses that I'm working with. So if that is the case and also, I have to tell you, I'm quite concerned about the deep disruption to privacy law that would occur if there was massive preemption. But be that the case, what if there was a way to do a surgical strike and provide guardrails in the areas that need it the most that would fill in the sectoral grant--gaps? That's what I'm very interested in.

So I think that something that had really important principles, Fair Information practices principles, and then the adaptation of those principles for the gaps that exist. So I do think that standards have been a neglected part of the privacy conversation. I have no idea why we don't have more standards in privacy. This mobile phone has loads of standards that attach to it but for our privacy and for data brokers, where are the standards? Well, let's create some, let's start there.

I'm all for starting cautiously and working with best practices too but to give things teeth and to abide by the--the larger principle. So a nice amalgamation of all the above, something that's multifactorial. I don't think we have silver bullets available to us anymore.

CRAPO: Well, thank you and just one other quick question and I'll turn to Senator Brown. We've talked a lot about the problems we're trying to address there, whether harm is caused by the use of data, whether credit is impacted, whether people are redlined or denied access to products or opportunities. It seems to me that when you--when you approach the issue from that perspective which is a very legitimate approach, that there is another issue that is--I don't know if I would call it a harm, maybe it is. But there's simply a privacy issue.

A lot of Americans I believe don't want to have to prove that they were harmed. They don't want people collecting data on them or they don't want certain data collected. It's sort of the right to be forgotten or the right to opt out of certain segments of data collection. Is that a legitimate right that we should try to protect?

DIXON: It's a legitimate option that we need to be able to have, the--the adversity score. I think that any child who's applying for college should be able to say, hey wait, I don't want my neighborhood being part of that. Do they have to prove harm? I don't think they should have to. They should be able to say, hey no, this is not something I want, it's legitimate.

CRAPO: Dr. Cackley.

CACKLEY: I think that's right that--that it's important for people to be able to make a choice about what data they share and what--and what data they don't.

CRAPO: Senator Brown.

BROWN: Thank you. Ms. Dixon, this is your last round of questions, blessedly for both of you and please be really brief on these because I have some trouble questions. Should federal regulators and supervisors have full access to every company's predictive models so they can evaluate them for bias and other legal compliance?

DIXON: I believe they would have to hire about a million people if they did that. I'm not sure of the answer to that question but I have a lot of thoughts on this and I will send you a written follow up.

BROWN: That would be good including is there a list of companies whose models you believe should be available to regulators for review maybe--

DIXON: Send that to you.

BROWN: Okay, technology expert our last hearing stated while our online economy depends on collection and permanent storage of highly personal data, we don't have the capacity to keep such large collections of user data safe over time. Do you agree with that statement?

DIXON: I think it's very difficult to keep user data safe 100 percent of the time.

BROWN: Should they be require--should companies be required to expunge certain types of user data after say 60 or 90 days?

DIXON: You know, there--I think there are very good arguments for that and there's a--there's a continuum for that and I will respond to that in writing.

BROWN: Okay thanks. Do companies who personally use--who currently use personal data for profit see existing penalties as little more than the cost of doing business that's--that's often the case in this town that a few million dollar fine on a multi-million dollar company is the cost of doing business. Did this strong--how strong do penalties and other enforcement mechanisms need to be in order to hold these companies accountable?

DIXON: I don't know the answer to that question. However, I do think that having very good enforcement is an important stick and I think we needs carrots and sticks to make things right.

BROWN: To holding executives account personally accountable one way?

DIXON: I don't know about that.

BROWN: (INAUDIBLE) or you just don't know?

DIXON: I literally don't know the answer to that.

BROWN: Okay, okay. A technology expert in our last hearing state was possible in principle to throw one's laptop into the sea and renounce all technology. It's no longer possible to opt out of a surveillance society. Do you believe that statement?

DIXON: Absolutely. I don't believe that an opt-out village exists.

BROWN: So what would a meaningful consent contract between users and tech companies or users and data brokers or meaningful opt-out policy look like?

DIXON: So it needs to be multifactorial and not just rely on consent because consent is a really difficult vehicle for that. I have a lot of very complete thoughts on that and I will follow up in writing.

BROWN: Okay, you're gonna be busy in the next few days.

DIXON: That's right. I have a lot on this so.

BROWN: And last question, you point out in your testimony household data can serve as a proxy for an individual credit score. Some data that seems innocuous like Instagram posts can actually yield predictive data about a user's mental health. How do we know what data is inherently sensitive and what data is innocuous but become--can become sensitive when it's used to make predictions?

DIXON: Right. One of the most difficult things that I've had to grapple with as a privacy expert and someone who cares so much about privacy is that it's so difficult to say here, this is sensitive data, here this is sensitive data. It's all becoming sensitive depending on how its analyzed and that's why privacy protections have had to become much more multifactorial and much more subtle and in responding to this new issue.

BROWN: In--in part, that--that that movement if you will from--that is initially not sensitive but becomes that as--as a result of just the--the power of computer--companies--the--the quantity and quality of computer--of computing power, correct?

DIXON: We were in a digital era. We're really moving into the predictive era and it changes everything.

BROWN: Okay, very good thank you, Mr. Chairman.

CRAPO: Thank you. And that does conclude the question for today's hearing. For senators who wish to submit questions for the record, those questions are due to the committee by Tuesday June 18th and we ask the witnesses to respond to those questions as quickly as you can once you receive them. Again, we thank you both for not only your time here today but the attention and--and analysis that you've given to this issue and we'll give to the issue as we proceed. With that, this hearing is adjourned.
